abstract: At $2.5 billion, Google’s breakup fee ranks among the five largest since 2000, according to data from Thomson Reuters.
snippet: At $2.5 billion, Google’s breakup fee ranks among the five largest since 2000, according to data from Thomson Reuters.
lead_paragraph: Google gave Motorola Mobility some sizable assurances that it was committed to buying the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion. As part of the deal, Google offered to pay a $2.5 billion reverse termination fee, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

headline.main: Ranking Google’s Hefty Motorola Breakup Fee

abstract: Google’s $2.5 billion reverse termination fee for Motorola Mobility sends a statement that the deal should clear antitrust review.
snippet: Google’s $2.5 billion reverse termination fee for Motorola Mobility sends a statement that the deal should clear antitrust review.
lead_paragraph: It is certainly big. But is there any chance that it will be paid? I’m talking about the $2.5 billion reverse termination fee that Google agreed to pay Motorola Mobility if its proposed takeover fails to obtain antitrust clearance. This fee is about 20 percent of the $12.5 billion deal value and is significantly higher than the $375 million Motorola Mobility must pay Google if it accepts another bid.

headline.main: Behind Google’s Huge Breakup Fee in Motorola Deal
